title: How many removals will U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement conduct in fiscal year 2017?
possible_answers: More than 500,000 but less than 1 million
preds: Timing makes higher numbers extremely unlikely

https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/return-rule-law-trump-administration-marked-increase-key-immigration-statistics The data released for Feb. 1, 2017 – July 31, 2017 is as follows:

Total Orders of Removal: 49,983
Up 27.8 percent over the same time period in 2016 (39,113)

Total Orders of Removal and Voluntary Departures: 57,069
Up 30.9 percent over the same time period in 2016 (43,595)

Total Final Decisions: 73,127
Up 14.5 percent over the same time period in 2016 (63,850)

I'm following danbell7819 on this one. Hurricane Irma is disrupting ICE's plans for rounding up illegals. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ice-plans-mega-largest-immigration-raid-operation-its-kind-n799691
Millions aren't leaving and neither are hundred of thousands really.

@Danbell7819 plus this: I also think Trump wants to downplay the fear associated with this type of action in light of his challenge to Congress on DACA to deal with it within 6 months. He quickly twittered that the Dreamers would all be okay following Nancy Pelosi's advice to twitter a message to calm the fear. So going for a big ICE operation doesn't play well on his DACA move in addition to the hurricane issues in Texas and Florida.

This NBC News article (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ice-plans-mega-largest-immigration-raid-operation-its-kind-n799691), and the subsequent denial of operations by ICE (https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/ice-statement-regarding-questions-enforcement-planning?wpmm=1&wpisrc=nl_daily202), are the best indicators to date that ICE is coming in well below Obama levels, as has been previously reported. While ICE could do some post-FY doctoring of the numbers, I'm more confident that it would take a wholesale methodology change than a simple fudging of close numbers.

14% decline in number of deportations relative to last year through June. "In previous years, the number of deportations was boosted by law enforcement officials apprehending more people just after they illegally crossed the U.S. border, said Matthew Bourke, an ICE spokesman. As fewer people enter the U.S. illegally on the border, “removals are going to be impacted," he said." decreasing probability of greater than 250k.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Updating for passage of time: removal rates have not picked up, and we are closer to the Sept. 30 deadline. That cuts the chances of more than 500,000 removals in half, bringing the probability down to 12.5%. However, I finally understand why the court backlog affects removal rates: when Trump removed the Obama policy that only serious criminals be targeted for arrest, he increased the amount of time each trial requires. Before, trials could be swifter on average, but now judges need to work through cases a little slower to make sure there are legitimate grounds for removal. In other words, removing serious criminals is faster than removing just any old illegal immigrant. This makes me 7% more confident that the low removal rates will continue--so I'm at about 95%.
http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/08/trump-deportations-behind-obama-levels-241420
Although arrests are up, overall deportations are down.

great comments by @anneinak and @danbell7819 trump is significantly behind obama unless he can push those numbers above 250k. i dont think this is negotiable for him - given the race and political (left of centre) leanings of Obama.it would seriously undermine his credibility with the rabid right.  i think it's actually become a priority push for him to showhis working class, right wing fan/voter base someof what he promised when they elected him, given his inability to move ahead with any of the other stuff, especially given the numerous cuts he's made to welfare, education, social assistance. i think he will include the in abstentia numbers, and i think he' s mounting a big push for the second half of the year with extra funding to ICE and Arpagio re-instatement. And, yes, definately think its likely he will fudge the numbers at year-end to be able to say he deported more than previous government who were supposedly 'soft' on this.

Given data so far this year, it would take a big boost in deportations to top 250,000. But I'm not ready to rule out a late year, big push by Trump.  Example of a wildcard: the Dreamers are easy to locate and deport, making them easier and faster to round up than any other class of potential deportees. . What about the inevitable outcry over sending people "home" to a country they last knew as toddlers, whose only crime was a poor choice of where they were born?  Comparison class: his pardon of Arpaio over the conviction of his defiance of a Federal injunction, which some see as signalling to targets of  Mueller's investigation that they can defy him. Get out of jail cards galore, ready to go. So Trump may care only about holding onto his base enough to make it political suicide in the Republican primaries for any impeachment proceeding to begin. Thus the otherwise unthinkable mass arrests and deportations of Dreamers might actually be worthwhile to Trump. CHAMPS KNOW checklist:
Yes: Comparison classes.  Provide relevant classes and calculate base rates.
Yes: Hunt for info. Share the evidence that helps inform your prediction.
N/A: Adjust. Explain the reason for updating your prediction.
N/A: Models. Explain any application of mathematical or statistical models.
N/A: Post-mortem. Interpret past failures and successes; draw implications for the future.
No: Select effort. Describe the optimal level of effort.
Yes: Know the power-players. Describe individuals with influence and how will they use it.
Yes: Norms & protocols. Describe laws, rules, scheduled meetings, etc., that matter.
Yes: Other perspectives. Describe bottom-up processes (protest, culture, market forces, technology, etc.) that may play a role.
Yes: Wildcards. Explain the sources and magnitude of uncertainty.

So I realized a significant error in one of my earlier forecasts (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/548415). In my analysis of EOIR case dispositions, I assumed that the increased deportation orders had resulted, or will result in, those numbers of immigrants deported. But as the Washington Post notes, "Justice officials have not said how many of the immigrants ordered deported were actually in custody — or if their whereabouts are even known. Every year scores of immigrants are ordered deported in absentia, meaning they did not attend their hearings and could not immediately be deported" (https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/immigration/trump-is-deporting-fewer-immigrants-than-obama-including-criminals/2017/08/10/d8fa72e4-7e1d-11e7-9d08-b79f191668ed_story.html?utm_term=.1894290d06e0&wpisrc=nl_daily202&wpmm=1). Correcting for my flawed assumptions, and using the numbers in the WaPo article as well as the Politico article first shared by @Anneinak (www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/548804), I'm adjusting my forecast higher on the below 250K mark.

Based on @Anneinak comment (www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/548804) and article. I hesitate to go all out for below 250K based on the increased productivity of the EOIR courts, with an increase in dispositions for removal (see www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/548415).

“The U.S. is deporting people more slowly than during the Obama administration despite President Donald Trump’s vast immigration crackdown, according to new data from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. From Feb. 1 to June 30, ICE officials removed 84,473 people -- a rate of roughly 16,900 people per month. If deportations continue at the same clip until the fiscal year ends Sept. 30, federal immigration officials will have removed fewer people than they did during even the slowest years of Barack Obama’s presidency. In fiscal year 2016, ICE removed 240,255 people from the country, a rate of more than 20,000 people per month.” http://politi.co/2vifRRu
Its a guess based on how I feel by looking at the question.

Slight downgrade to below 250K and slight upgrade to above 250K based on WaPo article: https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/immigration/deportation-orders-up-under-trump-fewer-prevail-in-immigration-court/2017/08/08/d3f0a6a6-7c74-11e7-9d08-b79f191668ed_story.html?utm_term=.9e37cad0251e&wpmm=1&wpisrc=nl_daily202. The 28% percent increase in EOIR deportation dispostions will likely push the number closer to, but still below, 250K based on the information we have available. Using the projected 226K from one of my earlier posts (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/536983), plus the approximate 10K that comprises the 28% increase from last year cited in the article, and factoring in another 5K buffer, and we end up around 241K for the year. You could add another 5K for an increased throughput in the EOIR system for the next two months (3K would be more in keeping with the current trend), which puts you at 246K. So still below the 250K mark. However, the math and statistics ICE uses are soft to say the least, and any change to the methodology could drastically alter the results (as happened between FY12 and FY13 - see https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/539673). But we won't know if ICE decided to count removals differently until the report comes out in December. It will be interesting to see if this question comes back for FY2018, given the steady filling of EOIR court justices by the administration coupled with internal ICE and DHS policy changes and decreased immigration rates at the SW border.

In general, the policy of using the law to deport the illegal immigrants that are breaking the law and are violent in nature will be a benefit to society at large.  However in my view, agribusiness will need qualified workers (legal and marginally legal) to provide labor for crop harvest production.   There must be some detail policy review and revision to allow for workers that are needed with a streamlined visa process.
An interesting perspective on the administration's approach to immigrants in the country: https://thinkprogress.org/trump-admin-deportation-ice-john-sandweg-d5030a140e63.
With expansion of expedited removals, the projected numbers could be higher than expected
For those interested in Southwest border apprehensions: https://www.cbp.gov/newsroom/stats/sw-border-migration.
They have busted a lot of people, but that pesky due-process thing will slow down the traffic.  Actual shipments should show a pretty big jump in the first and second quarters of next FY.

Since President Trump took office, more than 65,000 people across the country have been arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement — a nearly 40 percent increase from the same period last year.  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/07/21/us/immigration-enforcement-california-trump.html

With arrests trending higher than last year in the first few months of Trump's administration it is expected that actual deportations will also pick up in time. Unlikely that the number is flat to last year given the political significance of the issue and the actual trend.

The only reasonable indicator is the data which has been collected thus far on the number of removals. None of the explanations for the decline make logical sense to me, so that's all there is to go on. The real number will definitely be 500,000 or under, but the question is whether Trump's rates of ICE removals will look like Obama's first 6 years in office, when there were well above 250,000, or if they will be more like his last 2 years, which were just under 250,000. The answer depends on what factors caused a lower rate of ICE removals in 2015 and 2016. According to ICE, the lower rates were due to Obama's policy of prioritizing removal of criminal aliens (the idea is that when you focus your resources on finding, arresting, and prosecuting the criminals, you have fewer resources left over for removing the non-criminals). 
https://www.ice.gov/removal-statistics/2016 The problem with this explanation, however is that Trump has reversed Obama's prioritization policies, and yet ICE removals have not increased. I'm sure the reversal has had some effect, but there must be something else going on to explain the low numbers.
http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/28/politics/trump-deportations-slow/ One possible factor is that rates of immigration to the US continue to decline. It's hard to measure this, but border apprehensions are the best proxy. One problem with this explanation is that there's a huge court backlog of around 500,000 cases. Even if fewer people are arrested, there should be plenty for ICE to deport as the DOJ works through its backlog and orders more people to be removed. What gives?
http://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2017/05/border-apprehensions-down-again-april The backlog has also been proposed--ironically--as an explanation for why removals haven't increased under Trump. Even though ICE is arresting more people, it takes a long time for their cases to be heard and for illegals to be sentenced to removal. The average wait time for a hearing is 670 days. 
http://trac.syr.edu/phptools/immigration/court_backlog/ One problem with this explanation is that ICE removals under Obama were often quite high, even though the court backlog continued to increase year after year during his administration. Now this makes no sense at all. I've read in many places that the court backlog is a key limitation in the Trump administration's efforts to remove more people. Why, then, was Obama able to remove nearly 400,000 people per year during his first term in office? 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-immigration-judges-idUSKBN16A2NI Were there more immigration judges serving back then? I doubt it. In July 2016, there were only 273 judges serving. That doesn't tell us how many served when ICE removals were at their peek, though.
https://www.humanrightsfirst.org/sites/default/files/HRF-Backgrounder-Immigration-Courts.pdf Sessions just hired 50 more judges, who will start working sometime this year. But how soon?
https://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2017/04/20/sessions-announces-hiring-of-50-new-immigration-judges-n2315949
Let's use https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/07/17/immigration-arrests-up-deportations-down-under-trump/484437001/# to do math, shall we?
ICE has been stepping up its activities and this is resulting in increasing volumes. Courts remain a bottleneck but I expect trump to change the way the operate to exempt more people from them.

The backlog of deportations despite rise in arrests doesn't look good for breaking the 250k mark, but the number of border crossings has allegedly dropped by 40% under Trump, so I factored in the remote possibility of a resurgence in border crossing attempts in the wake of political unrest, natural disasters, or the likes. Even if there's a modest spike, that could inpact the removal stats as border arrests make up a big chunk of deportations (according to ICE reports linked in question). 
http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-border-apprehensions-20170309-story.html

If current trends continue, removal rates are trending below 250K (https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/07/17/immigration-arrests-up-deportations-down-under-trump/484437001/#). Using the monthly averages in the article (22,705/mo for Oct-Dec and 16,895/mo for Feb-Jun), using the 22,705 number for Jan to fill the gap for a higher end result, and carrying forward the 16,895 number for the remainder of the FY (3 mos), the number shakes out to about 226K (22,705*4 mos plus 16,895*8 mos). It's possible for increases in the last few months, but as the article noted, EOIR case backlog is now above 600K. As I've mentioned in other posts (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/529938, https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/495969, and https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/494679), this backlog and the challenges of removing large numbers of immigrants makes it unlikely the administration will be able to remove an additional 25K over the next 3 months to get above 250K.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Internal ICE memo authorizing arrest of all illegal immigrants irrespective of priority is bound to jam up the EOIR courts as their cases move forward, further slowing removal rates (https://www.cato.org/blog/unpublished-memo-allows-arrests-non-criminal-immigrants-who-trump-did-not-prioritize). There's only 2.5 months remaining to get above 250K, with no indications the WH is taking the necessary steps to relieve the logjam at the EOIR courts. Slight increase for below 250K. Plus, an interesting read on ICE's efficiency at migrant removal: https://www.oig.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/assets/2017/OIG-17-51-Apr17.pdf.

Updating to reflect higher confidence as closing date draws near. Quick google search shows things are on pace to remain under 250,000 this year. https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/massachusetts/articles/2017-07-11/us-deportations-of-europeans-on-track-to-exceed-last-year
Shifting a little toward under 250,000 as the deportation system has not received the extra resources it needs to process these people.

I'd consider 250,000 to be a baseline number.  Since it reflects Obama's final year in office, I'd bet the Trump administration for political reasons will press to surpass that figure in FY17, and to use the ICE deportation figures (to be released in December) to support Republican candidates in border states in November 2018 Congressional elections.

Q3 numbers should be coming out soon, but this Atlantic piece from May has some good info: https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/ice-arrests-increase-nearly-forty-percent/527427/.  This still comes down to the EOIR courts, which are not able to handle the crushing backlog of cases. And as ICE continues going after non-violent immigrants, it only adds to the casework and backlog, slowing the process down more. ICE may break 250K, but it will likely be by a small margin. Sticking with my 80/20 under/over.

https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/06/data-driven-deportation/531090/ if he can bypass the courts, due process, dt can send more than 250K away. Interestingly, this is one of the few things he does that garners scant press, public and grassroots attention and action

Given that the removals in 2016 were 240,255 and the arrests in 2017 are up compared to 2016, I am presuming that there will b a push before the end of 2017 to increase the removals. The average before 2014 was above 360,000 per year from 2008 through 2013 and was 315,943 in 2014.

I've seen nothing to suggest things are going different than my previous forecast, with Q4 approaching I'm hoping to find some information but otherwise feel more confident that the high level messes keeping attention from this  are causing enough distractions that there hasn't been a further push to increase the removal efforts.
250k represents what I would offer on an over/under proposition. ICE courts can be slow. Next year's number is more interesting. I would guess 350k for 2018 at this point.

I'm still skeptical that numbers *won't* increase under the Trump administration, but I'm seeing more and more evidence that the increase may not be substantial enough to push this in the  category I currently favor. Moving towards more uncertainty here.

Now that Trump has won the election, his priority (and the priority of his voters) would shift to fiscal policy and other big deals. The number will increase if Sanctuary Cities have to report illegals to ICE. Also, the number of deportation would decrease because there will be less illegals entering the country.

Removal is a term used when an illegal immigrant is removed from the US via a formal legal process. 
 Apprehension is a legal term and used when an illegal immigrant is put into custody and informally returned to country of origin.  The below link from the Migration Policy Institute gives a detailed breakdown of immigration actions by Clinton, Bush II and Obama.  In my opinion, Trump will focus on deportations over removals.  The process is less complex and the political gain will be the same.    http://www.migrationpolicy.org/article/obama-record-deportations-deporter-chief-or-not
 http://immigration.findlaw.com/deportation-removal/overview-of-removal-procedures.html

Lowered 1st category by 9% and raised 2nd category by that amount on anecdotal information from friends at Mexico City airport seeing large amount of deportees arriving. Still going to be push-back from farmers and industries that rely on undocumented employees. Texas legislature shoving match shows how passionate  both sides are.

With no recent statistical reporting from ICE, the trend continues towards the 250K removal mark, with the question being whether it is above or below that number. Removals are comprised of border removals, various administrative removals, and through the EOIR, or immigration, courts, as I've previously discussed (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/495969). With decreased attempts to cross the border, disconnects between ICE and local LE in major cities, and significant EOIR backlog, I sense that ICE will trend along FY16 levels of about 230-240K. As discussed previously, over 500K in the few remaining months of FY17 is nearly impossible, and removals of over 1 million migrants would break through the squelch of the 24 hour news cycle (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/494679). Since you're not hearing of tens of thousands of migrants being removed daily, it's safe to assume that anything over 500K will not happen before 1 October. ICE should have some updated numbers for removals at the end of June (end of Q3 FY17), so we'll know more then.

Although immigration arrests are up in 2017, deportations are actually below normal levels and not on pace to pass 250,000. There are a number of causes for this, as mentioned in a USA Today article:
"Homan said the agency removed 56,315 people from the U.S. in that time period, a 12% drop from the same period in 2016. He said that was due to a backlog in immigration courts, the time-consuming nature of deportations of undocumented immigrants living in the country and a drop in people caught crossing the southwest border, which often leads to quick deportations." (https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/05/17/deportations-under-president-trump-undocumented-immigrants/101786264/)

I don't think that it is Trump's real intent to remove 500,000 + people from the US.  It would probably have too much effect on the economy.  I think the numbers will increase to appear to keep campaign promises, but Big Business relies too much on such labor markets, as well as a good section on lower class citizens who will not work for certain wages or jobs.

Per discussions by fburdine and Iainhen99, there does not seem to be much rationale for the Trump administration increasing its removals. Reasoning includes: the precipitous drop in border apprehensions, which are a disproportionate component of removals; the drop in overall removals so far during the first three months of the Trump administration; high number of cases vs available judges, despite some increases in funding.  On the contrary, three months is only the beginning of a presidency so it seems to me that there could be some increases in efficiency with time. However, if removals for the very start of the 2017 FY were at 2016 average levels for the Obama admin, then dipped as we've seen, then returned to the 2016 Obama levels, they would still fall far short of 250K (as did the Obama admin in 2016). If Trump admin reverted to FY 2014 or earlier removal levels for ~half the current fiscal year, then they could reach above 250K.

This is a huge change for me as I've reconsidered thanks to a question from @fburdine. I'll just post my response below instead of rewording it for a stand alone post. 
___ Thanks for following up. I've been a bit less thorough on a few questions lately so any impetus to check assumptions is appreciated.  I had actually seen your comment above already and was one of the three people to have given it an upvote. I found the information compelling but had misremembered how the Obama administration's categorizing of ICE deportation statistics had been altered. It seems the change reinforces your prediction of not surpassing 250,000 deportations this fiscal year.  First, here is an excerpt from a July, 2016, report by the Center for Immigration Studies: http://cis.org/Immigration-Enforcement-Deportations-Decline-2016
"Most Deportations are Border Cases The great majority of deportations (72%) completed by ICE are border crossers who were initially arrested by the Border Patrol or port of entry officers and turned over to ICE for deportation. Most of the rest are aliens who were arrested in the interior, with only a handful of cases (less than 1%) initiated by other agencies. In previous administrations, border crossers did not make up a large share of deportations credited to ICE. The inclusion of hundreds of thousands of border cases in ICE deportation totals became the basis for deceptive Obama administration claims of “record deportations” beginning in 2012, when in fact, deportations resulting from interior enforcement were dropping sharply. Exposure of this statistical manipulation by the Center led then-incoming DHS Secretary Jeh Johnson to acknowledge that Obama administration deportation statistics are not comparable with those of previous administrations.2"
__________________ So, it seems that a big portion of the numbers from the Obama administration were from people who were caught at the border and returned in a matter of days. If this is true then it would matter how many people are attempting to cross the border illegally and being caught.  According to fairly recent reports this number continues to drop precipitously: http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/may/9/illegal-immigration-southwest-border-down-70-pct/ By Stephen Dinan and Andrea Noble - The Washington Times - Tuesday, May 9, 2017 Illegal immigration across the southwestern border is down a stunning 76 percent since President Trump was elected, with the flow of children and families dropping even faster as analysts say the administration’s commitment to enforcing the law has changed the reality along the border. Overall apprehensions by the Border Patrol dropped to just 11,129 in April, according to numbers released Tuesday, marking the lowest monthly total for any month in decades. The number of unaccompanied illegal immigrant children nabbed at the border dropped below 1,000 — a level not seen since before the surge that bedeviled President Obama during most of his second term... Border apprehensions are considered a rough yardstick for the overall flow of illegal immigration, so a drop in arrests is believed to reflect an overall drop in the flow of people. At its peak early in the last decade, the Tucson sector, which is just one of nine regions along the border, regularly recorded more than 70,000 apprehensions in a single month. Last month, Tucson reported fewer than 1,500 arrests. Activity has shifted to the Rio Grande Valley sector in Texas, with nearly 4,000 apprehensions in April. Still, that’s a fraction of the 22,000 apprehensions recorded in October and fewer still than the nearly 40,000 arrests at the peak of the Central American surge in 2014."
__________ Given the significant drop in people being captured at the border the easiest means of getting the numbers up will not be available to the Trump administration. Even if interior enforcement is increased significantly, it is very unlikely to make up the difference given that border crossers accounted for over 70% of deportations according to the CIS report linked to and quoted above.  Finally, given that the previous administration manipulated statistics to significantly inflate them versus previous reporting methods, I now think it unlikely that the current administration will be able to do anything to over report deportations by ICE in a consequential manner. Therefore, I am dramatically changing my prediction. Thanks again for the encouragement to reconsider.

https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/05/17/deportations-under-president-trump-undocumented-immigrants/101786264/ Immigration arrests up 38% nationwide under Trump
ALAN GOMEZ | USA TODAY
Updated 29 minutes ago
In the 100 days since President Trump signed an executive order to enhance immigration enforcement, the arrests of undocumented immigrants is up 38% from the same time period in 2016, according to Immigration and Customs Enforcement data released Wednesday. ICE Acting Director Thomas Homan said his agency is focusing on undocumented immigrants with criminal records, the "bad hombres" that Trump spoke about throughout his presidential campaign. But the data show that the biggest jump in arrests involved undocumented immigrants without a criminal record, a 156% increase from last year. Between Jan. 22 and April 29, ICE arrested 10,845 people whose immigration violations were the only marks on their record. That's nearly triple the 4,242 people arrested during the same time period in President Barack Obama's final year in office.

"Congress’s spending bill calls for 10 additional judges, but a look at the math suggests a lot more are needed.
... 
As of March, cases had been sitting there for an average of 669 days, up from 413 days a decade ago, according to Syracuse University’s Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse, or TRAC, which gathers such data.
...
The EOIR budget seems similarly insufficient for the workload. There are roughly 570,000 cases pending in court, according to TRAC. EOIR currently has funding for 374 judges, though only 311 of those positions have been filled. Each judge can process about 750 cases a year. Even with the 10 additional judges under the spending bill—and assuming those and all the other vacant judgeships could be filled and trained up immediately, which they won’t be—it would still take nearly two years to get through the current backlog. By which time even more cases will be waiting."

Thanks to danbell7819 for this useful article:
http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/28/politics/trump-deportations-slow/

This question hinges on how much the number of removals is really in Trump's control. On the one hand, border apprehensions for the last three years are down, and this is no doubt a key reason why removals are down, too. But another reasons might have to do with Obama's 2015 executive orders, which called for a focus on deporting convicted felons over non-criminals. Trump's reversal of these orders might contribute to higher deportation rates.  Below are two articles which offer rather different explanations for why removals declined during Obama's last 2 years in office.
http://www.npr.org/2016/08/31/491965912/5-things-to-know-about-obamas-enforcement-of-immigration-laws
http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/aug/05/national-border-patrol-council/interior-deportations-down-9-year-low/ Though there has been some interesting discussion about court backlogs putting a bottleneck on removal rates, I don't see how this would keep Trump's numbers lower than they were under Obama (who oversaw high deportation rates during his first 6 years in office). So I'm pretty sure it will just depend on the amount of immigration coming across the border (not a lot lately) and the reversal of Obama's Priority Enforcement Program (PEP).

Looking at EOIR (immigration) court data (https://www.justice.gov/eoir/page/file/fysb16/download), it appears that proceedings for removal have a 70% chance of ending in the migrant being removed at the initial case, with 96K migrants being removed in 2016 during initial case proceedings. If the case is referred to subsequent proceedings, which happens about 10% of the time, the percentage of verdicts for removal drops to about 30%, with 4.4 migrants removed after subsequent proceedings.  The more telling trend in this document is that the number of migrant removal cases adjudicated through other completions, defined as "[c]ases that are not decided on their merits," has tripled in the last five years, from roughly 15K in FY12 to over 48K in FY16. While it is unclear from the report if the majority of those migrant cases resulted in removal, it does indicate that the executive branch is exploring other means of continuing removals without relying on the backlogged immigration courts. Maintaining the same forecast as before based on my previous analysis, as actual numbers for the first half of FY17 are difficult to find.
The ICEman cometh, all right, but probably not until next FY.

Less than 250k were removed in FY 2016. While one might expect an even higher number to be removed in FY 2017 due to the Trump administration policies and actions, I believe that the lower level of illegal immigrants crossing the boarder into the US will mean there are less "additions" to be removed.

Some items to consider... Arrests are not a good metric. Border arrests/removals are primarily performed by the Border Patrol, a part of CBP. ICE, a separate agency, only handles a portion of border activity. ICE has about 8K agents working domestics investigations per FY16 PresBud (http://immigrationforum.org/blog/the-presidents-fy-2016-budget-department-homeland-security/). As such, to reach the 500K removal number, each agent would need to successfully remove 1 migrant every 4 days between now and the end of the FY. BUT... ...Arrests this year don't matter regarding the number of removals.  Immigration courts are jammed up with a backlog of over 520K cases pending (https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/01/us/deluged-immigration-courts-where-cases-stall-for-years-begin-to-buckle.html?_r=0). So ICE can arrest as many people as they like, but the deciding factor on removals is predominantly the courts. From this article: "The courts will be a major obstacle for President-elect Donald J. Trump and his plans to deport as many as three million immigrants he says have criminal records. Many of those deportations — at least hundreds of thousands — would have to be approved by immigration judges." And: "In the past two years, the administration won increases for the courts from Congress, and the number of immigration judges rose by 65 to about 300 today. But the hiring of judges is glacially slow. With each judge completing an average of 750 cases a year, the courts would need at least 520 judges to eliminate the backlog within one year, according to an analysis by Human Rights First, a watchdog group in New York." The immigration courts are so slammed due to delays in filling vacant positions. And politics is a major consideration. From the NYT article:  "Mr. Sessions could cancel the appointments of roughly 75 new judges selected by Attorney General Loretta Lynch to choose judges to his liking. But it might be a year or longer before they took the bench. And Mr. Sessions would not have authority to summarily reduce the backlogs, lawyers said." So the takeaway? To break 500K is nearly impossible, let alone getting over 1M+. This really comes down to the small portion of border arrests/removals ICE performs coupled with the average throughput of the immigration courts. And that 750 cases per day per judge, of which there are 300, comes out to 225K decisions, not all of which result in removals. Examining the trends of the immigration courts and the percentage of decisions resulting in removal will provide better clarity of this. The trend is leaning towards less than 250K. Going with 70/30 on the 250K number as I do more research.

So CNN reported this on Friday: http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/28/politics/trump-deportations-slow/ Based on the numbers cited from Inauguration until the end of April, which was roughly 55K (or 550 people/day), and assuming that was consistent with the period of Oct 1 2016 to Jan 20 2017, and will continue at roughly the same pace moving forward, the math works out to roughly 200K removals by the end of FY17.  Even assuming an uptick in the last ~150 days of the FY to over 1,000 people/day (essentially doubling current rates), it would still only put the total just over 260K. Assuming ICE has removed approximately 115K people to date (my estimate based on interpretation of data), to get over 500K, ICE would have to remove over 2,500 people/day. To get over 1 million would require over 5,900 people/day, and to get over 2M would require ICE to remove 12,556 people/day. ICE is a fairly small agency, and to expect it to remove over 1M, let alone 2M, people is beyond the abilities of the agency, let alone DHS as a whole. Also, don't forget that removals require ICE to process the migrants through legal processes, and while these can be expedited for a number of cases, there are a number that cannot be simply pushed through. And if ICE decided to start arresting over 12K people a day, it seems likely that the number of legal challenges, not to mention lawsuits by watchdog orgs and NGOs, would slow down the deportation machine, perhaps below current levels. Revising my numbers based on further research. There are no indications that ICE is capable of approaching anywhere near 2,500K people/day, so we're really talking about an over-under on 250K for FY17. And current data and trends favor the under.  Finally, an important note buried in the methodology of ICE's 2016 report (https://www.ice.gov/removal-statistics/2016), is that there is a "lag" between numbers on Oct 1 2017 and the final numbers reported out. Since this question ends on 30 Sep, you should factor in a little cushion to account for this "lag".

It’s way more than the immigration courts can handle. So it’s not like you’re being soft on enforcement or dialing back on enforcement, it’s just that you’re targeting the enforcement.”
